awd_titl_txt: NeTS: Small: Collaborative Research: Enabling Robust Communication in Cognitive Radio Networks with Multiple Lines of Defense
awd_abstract_narration:
Opportunistic spectrum access (OSA) is at the core of the cognitive radio technologies with the focus on improving spectrum utilization efficiency and reliability. Despite the benefits, existing OSA protocols suffer from their deterministic nature and cannot prevent an ill-intended jammer from disrupting legitimate communications. A cognitive jammer can always effectively jam the idle channels by exploiting public-available channel statistics and causes serious spectrum underutilization. This project addresses the challenge of establishing robust anti-jamming communication in cognitive radio networks (CRNs) through a multiple-line of defense approach. The research considers a variety of network environments and integrates defense technologies from different dimensions, including adaptive uncoordinated frequency hopping (AUFH), power control, and signal processing. The defense approach enables both reactive and proactive protections, from evading jammers to competing against jammers, and to expelling jamming signals, and thus ensures robust user communications in CRNs. 

The research in this project has a potential to significantly advance the state-of-the-art and develop innovative and sophisticated defense strategies using the proposed multiple lines of defense approach. The proposed solutions will contribute towards eventually building robust and dependable CRNs that are critical to the future communication systems. The project will also contribute directly to the curriculum development, teaching, student supervising and future security engineer training. Major results of this project will be disseminated through presentations, publications, as well as online materials in the forms of tutorials and software packages.

por.por_cntn:
The project started as collaborative research, with Dr. Kui Ren of SUNY, Buffalo forming the other end of the collaboration.  The original envisioned goal of the project was to understand the most critical challenges posed by jammers in the specific context of cognitive radio mesh networks, and undertake research tasks to address specific research challenges in that space.  Once the project started, the attention of the NCSU team was focused on these concerns in mesh networks, and network layer methods rather than link layer methods, as well as the inclusion of broader security/dependability metrics for wireless networks, and subsequently, in generalizing these concepts in the wired backend network.

Our research bore fruit on several fronts in these directions.  We investigated the distinction between the average performance delivered by a mesh network and performability (availability weighted performance) - we showed that there does not in general exist a transmission power (or node density) that can maximize both availability and performability.

We also analyzed a routing-based approach to jamming mitigation that we had previously developed, now in the context of wireless mesh networks. Using control theory, we posed the routing problem as one of a series of control decisions for the network, which can then be analyzed to provide bounds on the reliability, and also provides a guide to modeling the reliability obtained by using a previous routing that we called "petal routing" because of the typical shape of the geographical region formed in forwarding a message.

Our next foray was to extend such distributed geo-diverse routing to airborne networks.  The problem is particularly challenging because the nodes are not only mobile, but there are absolute planning requirements on this mobility (trajectory planning) due to the requirements of (a) not crashing into each other or obstacles, and (b) achieving the desired progress of the drone swarm. We addressed the problem under a class of abstract missions for UAV platoons called ?plume wrapping? that was general enough to capture a range of airborne mesh network control problems, including detecting, avoiding, and/or delineating a region of some particular characteristic. We showed that our algorithm can accomplish this without any central control whatsoever, by purely local control.

We also considered how the problem of jammer localization, and indeed the concept of jammer itself, generalizes under the distributed services network scenario.  In such a case, it is reasonable to consider the source of some malicious traffic to be the equivalent to the "jammer".  Viewed like this, the analogue to a sophisticated jammer becomes essentially a botnet.  Botnet detection is difficult under partial data.  We showed that some approaches, while equally effective as others given full collaboration, degrade less gracefully than others when an increasing fraction of the many ISPs (that are network owners and operators) choose not to collaborate by sharing traffic data.  Based on this, we further went on to design our own botnet community detection algorithm that can not only operate effectively on partial data, but can utilize the known structure in communication networks for much faster operation.

Our project also attempted some hands-on work and implementations.  Notably, we measured the performance of a jammer localization algorithm in multi-AP WiFi networks in our SenseNet testbed to determine its practical limits.  However, we acknowledge that we did not end up being able to do as much hands-on work in this project as we had originally envisaged.  The main challenge we had was the temporary unavailability of qualified students who were or could be interested in this area, due to the areas of Machine Learning and Deep Learning gained significant visibility during exactly this time.  Interest in those areas exploded among our student population, as well as among employers.  Although this came at a bad time for our project, since then the student interest has re-stabilized, so it is not a lasting problem for hands-on work in networking and communications areas.  Nevertheless it remains a fact that during this particular project, we were able to create less impact on this front than we had hoped, and accordingly returned a substantial part of our budget to NSF at the conclusion of our project.

Notwithstanding, the large number of research units we were able to complete, and publish results on, constitute a very successful research project overall.  Every one of these research units, apart from their own value, also indicate promising directions for further research, some of which we are following.  The web-accessible public archive we have created at http://winetsec.csc.ncsu.edu is another key outcome of our project.  It provides detailed information about each of the research unit we undertook, with source code, data, and additional explanatory material wherever appropriate and available.  We hope and expect this archive will allow other researchers beside us to build on our research output, and create lasting value from this funded project.
